p:
Crossing data from large databases - the GBIF, eMonocot, and GID
62 databases – we compiled 2,550,396 occurrences representing 15,901 species from 1,497 genera on 5,565 islands. Although this seems to be a small proportion of the initial sample (180,495 islands), suggesting that more sampling efforts are needed, this represents one of the largest dataset used for large scale conservation studies in islands. The use of eMonocot allowed reducing taxonomic and geo-localization errors and uncertainties, and therefore gave us more confidence in the validity of our data compared to using GBIF alone
72 . It also allowed to exclude non-native species, complete and correct a species’ area of distribution, and check for synonymies.
